rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: Professor Reinert is an awesome human being and has this incredible self-deprecating humor that you wouldn't expect at first. Extremely knowledgeable in his field, has a passion for literature that I've never seen before. He's a tough grader on essays, but let's you rewrite them.  There are readings for every class, but they're typically short.

Professor Reinert is one of the best professors I've had at UNC. My class was on 18th-Century British Literature, which sounds boring, but he made it so engaging. He always cracked witty jokes and tried his best to engage students with the material. I worried about this class because I'm not a fan of reading or history, but I loved it. I recommend.

While I wouldn't describe his class as an Easy A, Thomas teaches one of the most interesting classes I've taken and holds awesome class discussions with minimal lecturing.  He also brings a lot of his own personality into the classroom, which really made it come alive.  As for grading, he lets you re-write all the papers as many times as you want.
Highly Recommend!!!

Great teacher. His assigned books are interesting, and class discussion is lively and engaging. A really cool guy who wants you to do well both in his class and in life. I'm not really an "english person" but I couldn't help myself from speaking up in his class because unlike other english courses his is not intimidating and/or dull.

Funniest professor I've had at UNC, an absolute delightful class to attend. Professor Reinert truly wants you to succeed, and makes final as easy as possible. Three papers are the course workload, the first two you're allowed to rewrite until satisfied with your grade. Absolutely recommend.

GREAT TEACHER.  So funny and lovable.  Really cares what his students have to say.  Never puts down any ideas or opinions.  Learned everyone's name in the class.  Chose mostly amazing books to read and discuss.  Never was really much into required reading, but I really enjoy this class because of him.

A really good professor. He chose interesting books to read and did a good job focusing on key themes and interesting passages. The papers were easy and you could rewrite them. He really likes hearing alternative interpretations from different people and doesn't shut people down just because he disagrees. HIGHLY RECOMMEND!!!!

he's the best professor i've had at unc. i love coming to class everyday, and he makes the material so interesting and...moving.  I know that sounds corny, but it's true.  He's a genius, he's hilarious, and he really tries to get to know the students as people.  TAKE HIS CLASS, you won't regret it.
he's awesome, very eccentric, and he makes even the boring material interesting.
He is a great professor! He made the material so interesting and I really enjoyed coming to class! I highly recommend him.(Also- he lets students re-write papers!)
Great professor! I looked forward to coming to his class every day. . . he's very humorous and eager to teach if you are willing to learn.

Excellent teacher...extremely funny, made material very interesting. Made it a point to know everyone's name and treat everyone like an individual. Allows paper rewrites too-it's hard not to get an A in the class if you do the reading, put in the effort, and contribute in class. Easily one of the best profs I've had...

funny guy who makes class ok, though it's all about poetry. the only grades are 3 papers and final but you can boost your grade by talking in class. you can re-write your papers too.  "i think snoop dogg is amazing."
great, self depracating sense of humor.  genuinely cares about students' understanding of the material.  allows resubmission of papers for additional points.

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: Take her class on postmodernism. She knows what she's talking about, and she is an excellent thinker. Very mind-boggling, but if you want to learn from someone who will make you rethink what you thought, take her class. A great mind and she takes what she does seriously. She gives her job as a professor her all; professional, highly intellectual.

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: Where do I begin? Imagine Dr. Phil and Oprah have a tree-hugging love child. That is Todd Taylor, or as he will make you call him, Coach Todd, because as he says himself, "I, ladies and gentlemen, will be your life coach from here on out." This is English 105, this is a joke class. He is no joke, this guy grades harshly. So much unnecessary work.
cool man

Coach Todd Taylor was the best professor I've had, and probably will ever have, at UNC. You will walk out of his classroom and see writing in a whole new perspective. Coach makes you work, but you will be grateful in the end. He is well-respected in the UNC English Department. I cannot be more thankful for taking this class.
You will not get an A

Todd is a cool dude, but he's so knowledgeable about films and expects you to be too. Class is easy during the semester, but the final and midterm are painful. Would say it was incredibly interesting and fun! Would recommend

I didn't really enjoy English before taking his class, but after I really enjoyed writing. He takes up time with his students in mandatory office hours helping you with your writing. If you put forth effort in the writing assignments, and show improvement you will be fine. If you make your writing personal, you will get a good grade.

Class is definitely worth taking but not an easy A.  You need to study for the exams-which are painstakingly LONG! I actually don't know what kind of professor he is because he rarely addresses the class.  Discussion takes place in recitation, led by a TA.  Films are hit and miss and several directors are repeats. Diversity would be nice.
fun elective class.  gain new appreciation for film.  professor is awesome!

AMAAAAAAAAAAZING.  awesome and amazing. mister todd taylor is the most incredible, GENIUS, creative, interesting, hilarious, influential people in the entire university.  take this class.  it'll change your life, i swear.  you will learn so much and love film so much more because you will begin to watch them from an entirely different perspective.  HE IS AWESOME.

ABSOLUTELY LOVED THE CLASS!!!! Work load was great and I felt all the assignments were beneficial esp. recreating a scene from a film. Tests were long but not too difficult if you actually watched the films.
No Comments

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: Professor Barbour is one of the smartest people I have ever met and definitely my favorite professor. Prepare for close readings and a lot of tough/conflicting ideology. He is very helpful in his office hours and makes an effort to know everyone in his class. He really believes in his students and their abilities and he's so encouraging!

Dr. Barbour is my favorite professor at UNC. He is obviously a genius and knows all the texts backwards and forwards. He will make you work for it, and the papers are really long, but they are worth it. His lectures are passionate and intense.

Possibly the hardest class I took my first semester, but worth it. He's an amazing lecturer and is extremely knowledgeable. Very passionate on the subject and obviously an expert in his field. However, he is also a tough grader and there is a lot of reading and analysis. And usually the prompts won't be things that we studied. Overall a good class.

Professor Barbour was a great professor who consistently and enthusiastically helped students. He was very passionate about his subject; he worked hard to make the subject material somewhat interesting and while it was a bit of work to do well, it was definitely worth it.

Rapid lecturer, but don't be intimidated! Happy to help with papers, and a very nice guy. That said, start papers early and edit carefully. Three shorter papers and one long research paper, but the midterm isn't bad at all. A brilliant prof who is clearly an expert in his field. Lecture-based, not as much discussion. Take it!

This is my favorite professor ever.  Not only in the English department but the whole school.  He teaches at a fast pace with the ultimate enthusiasm.  I have taken him three times since being a student at UNC.  Take his class, you will not regret it and you will learn so much.

He is an awesome professor. I was intimidated by him at first because he paces and yells throughout lecture, but he keeps things interesting. I learned a lot in this class. Recitations are pointless, but the TAs are nice and helpful.

Probably the most I've EVER learned in a class. Barbour is incredibly knowledgeable and his lectures are always fascinating. A great help on writing papers, in everything from choosing a topic to proofreading. He's funny, but also intellectually demanding, serious, and thought-provoking. Highest recommendations (plus he brings his dog in sometimes)

The man basically paces in front of the class for an hour every day and yells at you.  Not a bad sort of yelling.  Just an animated exclamation of everything you could possibly want to know about Milton.  Be prepared for a fast pace.  He's amazing.  And very helpful when it comes to paper-writing.

WOAH this guy knows absolutely everything about the 17th century. Take good notes! His exams just ask you to spit back what he said in class. Super helpful with papers. I've never had a more enthusiastic teacher. Loved his class.

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: I had her for a first-year seminar on Jane Austen. She was interesting...She's really nice but is a stereotypical english teacher who gets lost in poetry, closes her eyes, and smiles for a bit. Kind of awkward. Can be annoying but overall, nice.

She is a really sweet person with a pretty quirky personality. There is a quiz at the beginning of every class so reading is mandatory, but she frequently lets class out early. Definitely recommend--makes romanticism fun and interesting!

Absolutely dreaded her class!!! She was not interesting and my idea of learning is not memorizing what poems go with what authors. There was way to much reading for the class and not enough time spent on the poems.

I found writing essays for her very difficult. She's not very clear as far as what she wants. However, I did go and talk with her on a couple different occassions and after talking with her things always seemed to get better. Just make sure she knows your name from the first day and everything will be fine. You'll find she's very approachable.

I could never imagine this woman being referred to as a "sweetheart." Her close-minded views and general idiocy has corroded any semblence of decent humanity.  Stay away if you're looking for an honest, fair exposure to Romanticism.

This professor taints the entire academic experience. She blatantly ignores key authors of Romanticism in order to trumpet her own uber-feminist views. As a female student, I took offense to her close-mindedness. She is rude and cold. Stay away if you believe in academic integrity.

Extremely biased and closed-minded. Incredibly nasty and disrespectful IF YOU GET ON HER BAD SIDE (read: express an opinion she does not agree with). About as unprofessional a professor as I have ever encountered.
Great teacher.  Moskal is a sweetheart as well as a good instructer.
She's a good professor, and I like how her class is structured (only 4 grades).  There's a LOT of reading, though, and the book is the heaviest one I've encountered here.

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: Great lecturer, highly interesting stuff. He's passionate about what he teaches.
Amazing professor in the English Department at UNC!!! Would definitely recommend. Just attend class and exams are easy.

Gura is one of my absolute favorite professors at UNC. He is EXTREMELY KNOWLEDGEABLE about early American Literature, so I would absolutely recommend him for ENGL 343.  Literally go sign up for that class right now. He's enthusiastic about the subject matter and has reasonable expectations for students. LOVE HIM!!!!
Gura is the best English teacher I've had at UNC. He is the kind of instructor who invites you to absorb the material instead of learning for the test. TAKE HIS CLASS if you love literature!
Great prof--extremely interesting, clear lectures, funny guy, and fair grader. Assignments are reasonable. Expert on what he teaches... check out the books he's written!
Gura is a great professor. I really hated literature before I took his class. Very entertaining. By the way, in my experience he is fair with all students and very friendly.

What a brilliant guy! I never thought I could be interested in this subject matter, but he really showed me how great puritan literature was. He was so passionate on the subject, and what a great beard, too!
this professor isn't very frendly and he favors girls he likes
This guy was awesome.  If you show some interest for the subject matter and go to his office before writing papers you will make an A.
I had him for a summer school english class...what an interesting professor! love the bluegrass, too...
not a very friendly guy but interesting lectures

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: Matchinske is great! Good lectures too. Sadly she takes attendance and it really counts. She's great in office hours if you want to discuss paper topics and really loves teaching and Shakespeare. You'll read only 8 plays (which I thought was too few) and have two 8-10 pg papers plus quizzes and she's not a tough paper grader. Recommended!

I have always loved Shakespeare but this teacher ruined it for me. I took English 225. Her lectures are fine and class time was bearable but her only grades are reading quizzes and 2 8-10 page papers. She grades the papers with extreme difficulty and does not give very helpful comments.
Loved this professor and will try to take many more classes with her! Very clear and very fair, and is a bit eccentric but loved her anyways!

Megan wears smocks and seems like a feminist; didn't seem like my kind of teacher. Her lectures were great, she truly surprised me. Go to class, stay engaged, read your stuff. If you ever have questions, go and talk to her. She's super insightful and taught me to read deeper (in all aspects).
Megan was an awesome teacher.  She is very smart and very helpful.

If you like films, then maybe you'll like this class. Many of the films were pointless. Lectures were scattered & even though she uses powerpoint, she gets off track often. My TA saved this class for me.
Excellent, thoughtful professor who made me look at things in different ways. Made me enjoy Shakespeare more than I thought possible.

I wouldn't say she's one of the best professors I've had, but she's not horrible. Her lectures for Engl 225 often get boring because it seems like she over-analyzes every little detail, which seems unnecessary to a non-English major. The plays are amazing though and they are the main reason I loved this close. Her TAs are more interesting, but she
Fun and engaging

Ms. Matchinske is really an excellent teacher & makes the most potentially dreary topics come to life.  I never understood why she thought that Lady MacBeth should be a role model to all women, but it was her opinion, which she is certainly entitled to.  Nonetheless, I was cautious when she held the sharp letter opener. H.John LaVine

I've taken Megan for both Shakespeare and Milton.  Let me just say she's one of my favorite all-time profs.  She's really good at shepherding discussion in interesting directions and opening up elements of the text you would never have noticed.  She's also incredibly friendly, funny, and just an all-around nice person.  This is not to say her class
No Comments

I am not an English major, so I found the 2 10 page papers very difficult. It is also hard to tell what is important during lecture, since there is a TON of reading. She is not easy to get an appointment with BUT if you can go see her about your paper she can help you a ton. 2 papers count 45%, a final worth 40% and participation and attendance 15%

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: McGowan has been teaching for a long time and is a walking encyclopedia. His class is discussion style and almost completely run by the students. He does expect you to read just about every night and submit a reading log. The toughest part was how boring and confusing some of the readings were! McGowan is awesome, but the reading selections weren't
I had him for a first-year seminar and it was absolutely amazing. He's the best professor I've had to date and is very forgiving, doesn't throw the book at you just because he can.
Dr. McGowan is terrific.  He is my favorite professor at UNC.  If you pass up a class of his, you are missing out.

A very engaging, shrewd, and yet also self-effacing professor.  You get the impression there's nothing he hasn't already read.  He's an extremely eloquent lecturer capable of making very abstract topics seem graspable.  A tough grader on papers, but reasonable.  I wouldn't hesitate to take another of his classes.

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: Dr. DeGuzman is super helpful and very nice. If you need help on a paper or want to understand the material better she's there to help you out. You have to read the novels to pass, but it's worth it as she chooses some really interesting reads. Not like any American lit class I've taken before. Beware the final though, it's tricky.

Getting Dr. D to direct my honors thesis was the hands down the best academic decision I ever made. I'm a better writer, researcher, and thinker as a result of working with her. It was a lot of work, but it was so fun!

An amazing academic and literary experience. I did not leave her class with a notebook full of notes that would lie forgotten; I left her class with a head full of ideas and new perspectives. She does not give exams, preferring papers instead. She gives a lot of reading, but it is always really engaging. Dr. D is among the best at UNC.

This was, seriously, the most amazing class I've ever taken in my life. I would pretty much do anything to take another course from Professor DeGuzman. She is one of the most intelligent people I've ever met, and she makes an effort to engage all of her students. Funny, makes course work interesting, great class dicussions. TAKE HER CLASSES.
She was sooooo good.  I loved her class.  She keeps you on the edge of your seat all class long... every class!
She was soooooo interesting.  Every class flew by!  You should totally take this professor if you get a chance.
AMAZING!
easy grader on essays, open to questions from students and easy to talk to, but class was boring

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: The course content was interesting, but our class did not have sufficient time to talk about the books that we read because sometimes she over-planned our classes and discussions felt very calculated and stilted. At first we thought that we understood what she expected, but as our projects progressed she made harsh critiques & diminished creativity
Amazing teacher. She is not only very gifted in her field, but a kind and wonderful person. Her class was my favorite. 5 stars.

She is a joy to have as a professor. She helps you increase your self confidence as a writer as well as empowers her students to discover inner meaning. This class was a significant amount of work (average homework per class was 2-3 hours) but I felt like I learned a lot and created a great relationship with a professor along the way.

She is a great professor who really cares about her students. This FYS was a lot more work than many others, but it was very rewarding. I really grew as a writer through the course. She also gave great, honest, fair feedback. Cons: The class is a big time-commitment, very reading and writing-intensive. But if you make good revisions, A is possible.
The best

she's great! just do your work throughout the semester and you'll do fine. you write four papers over the course of the semester and then turn in your final portfolio at the end which is your grade. guaranteed a b if you do all the work.

SHE IS FANTASTIC! One of the best professors I have ever had-- makes class extremely interesting. She assigns quite a bit of reading, but makes it doable. I learned a lot in her class and I'm looking forward to her class again next semester.
A fantastic teacher, and, by the way, VERY beautiful!

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: One of my FAVORITE professors at UNC! I have taken two of her comparative literature classes (Romancing the World and Don Quixote) and plan to take more if possible. There is a lot to read but her lectures are always so interesting and insightful.

One of my favorite professors so far at UNC. As long as you come to class and do the readings, you will pass. Some of the readings were boring, but others were great and interesting (about half and half). Professor Collins truly cares about each student and what they learn from her. I would take this again.
She is the sweetest teacher. Her tests are very hard/specific, but she grades papers fairly. Lots of reading per class, but I would definitely recommend her!

I was delighted to have my senior seminar with Dr. Collins. For starters, she is SUCH a sweet, ebullient lady. She chose interesting texts, kept class discussions lively, and was reasonable with expectations/feedback. Also super knowledgeable in Renaissance lit and Cervantes.  If I hadn't graduated I'd be in her classes all the time!

I enjoyed this class because I love literature but I have a friend in the class who does not and she thought it was miserably boring. Overall, very easy if you read the books and attend lecture every now and then.

I took CMPL 390 - Don Quixote with Prof Collins and LOVED it. Stay on top of the readings, attend class and participate occasionally and you'll make an A. The tests weren't difficult if you did the reading and paid attention. Prof Collins is incredibly intelligent and very helpful! Definitely take her class!
Collins' lectures are very boring, she reads them directly from a piece of paper and they tend to be pretty unnecessary. You don't have to attend lecture very often to get a good grade in the class.

Dr. Collins is sooooo nice and very helpful. She really knows the material very well, and she is encouraging to all students. I learned so much from her. My only comment is that it would be better if she taught classes all in Spanish instead of English.

Dr. Collins is the best professor! She is very helpful, kind and patient, and she really knows her stuff. She works with both Golden Age and Twentieth Century Spanish lit and is well-versed in both. Her classes are not easy, but they are worth taking, and if you work hard you will do well.

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: Dr. Wolfe is really great! Knows her stuff, and is super passionate about it. ENGL 120 has some pretty dry material, but she makes it bearable. Super understanding of how busy our schedules can be, and is always willing to meet and go above and beyond to help you.

Take a class with her! She is one of the best professors I have had at UNC, and is both a true scholar and a dedicated, kind person who cares about students.  She's willing to meet & edit your papers all of the time, and has even told us that she grades all of the papers in her lectures. Very passionate about literature and helps you dive into it.

A fantastic professor that is an expert on her subject. She will keep you engaged and passionate about her class. I strongly recommend that you fight to get into a small, honors class with her, because she will edit all papers and meet anytime.  I would recommend her to anyone, and you should take multiple classes with her because she gives recs.

Dr. Wolfe is absolutely brilliant and one of my favorite professors at UNC. I knew very little about the topic of classical poetry before taking her class and now I have several new favorite authors and topics. She is sure to keep you engaged, expose new interests, and help you dive into the ancient texts. Have fun!

Absolutely brilliant professor. So knowledgeable and always gives very interesting lectures. Class had 3 essays and an essay-based final, so very writing intensive. She is very accessible and helpful with these papers. Overall, a must have professor at least once.

Professor Wolfe is such an interesting professor. She really knows her stuff and I learned a ton from her class. Lectures are very interesting, though recitation kind of sucks. She grades papers pretty critically, but if you take time on it you can get a B easy. Final was a take home paper, which is great. Overall, great experience.

Jessica Wolfe is one of the best professors for comparative literature/english at UNC. Her teaching style is pretty unique (she speaks really fast!) but its not unfollowable. Keep up with the reading and you should be fine.

Professor Wolfe was very enthusiastic and occasionally humorous. During the last lecture, she said the material wouldn't appear on the final exam, and she joked, "This is the part where half of the class is supposed to leave," but everyone stayed. The text was difficult to understand, but she clarifies the text in class. Beware: She does talk fast.

I really just can't say enough good things about Jessica Wolfe. She honestly opened my mind to an entire genre -- I used to find classic, epic literature dry and dull, and she revealed the complexity in each novel. What a great professor! So smart, approachable and cool. Can I be her when I grow up?

Dr. Wolfe is by far one of the best teachers I've ever had. She is a brilliant lecturer and extremely helpful outside of class. Her grading is rough but she makes it so easy to do well by providing so much extra assistance and AMAZINGLY INSIGHTFUL lectures. She talks insanely fast and not a minute of time is wasted but it's all worthwhile. =)

Absolutely brilliant, enthusiastic about what she teaches, engaging and exciting at the same time that she blows your mind with her insights. She goes WAY out of her way to meet with you outside of class. Grades tough but fair, reading is very light (and not even necessary if you pay attention). Serious business, but so nice! A must-take teacher!
No Comments

She's a wolfe in sheep's clothing! Yeah, she looks small and meek, and young for a tenured professor, but this woman really knows her stuff, especially Shakespeare. The only complaint I have is that she doesn't lecture much but spends most of her time on class discussion. Still, one of the best English profs you can get.
She doesn't waste a second of class and flies through her lectures, and she's no pushover.  The final was difficult and she required two long papers.  But she knows her stuff.

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: One of UNC's finest professors! I took her Shakespeare course in the fall and loved her as a professor so much that I took her Renaissance course the following semester. She is a tough grader, but the classes are very enjoyable. Totally worth it!

Floyd-Wilson leads interesting and usually engaging lectures about plays that can sometimes come off very dry. She lectures rather than leading a class discussion, which I enjoyed. She assigns two papers, and has a midterm and a final. The midterm & final are both passage id heavy, so paying attention to the themes and passages in class is crucial
Rewarding class, but can be tough.

Dr. Mary Floyd-Wilson was BY FAR one of the nicest, most approachable, and friendly of my professors. I took ENGL 225 as a freshman and, being in an upper-level English class made me nervous, but she certainly made the transition easy. She is very enthusiastic about her subject, and likes to see her students share that enthusiasm.
Very helpful.  Enjoyed class and it is evident that she cares about her students and is very willing to help.  Classes are never boring and she is very helpful in office hours.  Definitely recommend!

Professor Floyd-Wilson is EXCELLENT. She is incredibly knowledgeable. Her lectures are really interesting and if you attend and do the readings, you will do well. This is the second class I've taken with her and I'd take one again in a second! DON'T take Armitage over her as previously suggested-I've taken classes with both and she is FAR superior.

Easily one of the best teachers I have had.  I had trouble early in the class, but Dr. Floyd-Wilson helped me so much.  She has high standards, but she helps you meet them.  She's also pretty funny.  If you're going to take Shakespeare get in her clss!

She is very animated which makes boring texts seem a little bit more interesting.  She is also very willing to give extra credit if you need it.  If you come to class and take good notes, you will do very well on the tests.

She was terrific. The class was mostly discussion, and they were never boring. She read rough drafts and helped me a ton with my paper.  She also gave us the exam questions ahead of time. Highly recommended.

I was not in Dr. Floyd-Wilson's recitation section, but I really enjoyed her lectures.  She was funny and really smart.  The tests were tough, and to do well you had to do the reading and attend the lectures.  I really liked this class. :)
This was a big lecture class, 150 students.  Lectures were smart and funny, though they move fast!  TAs lead discussion sections.  Exams were tough but fair if you went to lecture.

Dr. Floyd-Wilson was BY FAR the worst prof I have EVER HAD in all my years at UNC. She reads prepared lectures, grades difficultly and inconsistently on exams, and is extremely unhelpful if not unfair. I NEVER complain about my profs- but Dr. Floyd-Wilson was definitely the worst. I heard Armitage teaches the best Shakes class. Do NOT TAKE this one

The prof. was a great lecturer. Her test were based on lectures. She expected that students had done the readings, and treated the students as competent adults. She is very clear and sometimes entertaining. I  would recommend this course to any student who is not trying to sleep through college.

She's got an unusual lecturing style; basically reads pre-prepared speeches. But they're always interesting and insightful, and she's very approachable if you have questions outside of class time. There's also the added bonus that all tests are based entirely on what she says in lecture, so if you go, you're good.

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: Best professor and for that matter human being I have ever met. Her depth of knowledge and encouragement for all her students is simply amazing. I hated English and the Humanities, and after taking two classes with her, she has instilled a new love for English and the Humanities in me. You need to take at least one class with her at UNC.
Very student friendly, but also knowledgeable beyond just in English. It's a fun class to take, but you should be ready to spare time for readings.

All around great teacher. The class was super easy. In the beginning of the year she told us that the way the grades worked, we could skip every recitation (which was simply a reading quiz and open discussion) and still pass with an A. She was really good with extra credit, and I never really had to read a burdensome amount. No tests ever.
SHE IS AWESOME. A must-have at UNC. Science major, history major, english major-- whoever you are, from whatever walk of life, this is the place to be. Don't miss out.

Even though it was just a seminar, Prof. Thrailkill was awesome! She is a little unorganized, and I don't think a normal english class with her would be necessarily easy, but she is an amazing professor and clearly has a passion for English.  A lot of reading, but can get away with not doing it all.

Do not give up a chance to take a class with this amazing professor. She is brilliant, funny, warm, engaging, and she obviously loves what she does. ENGL 268 is easily one of the best classes at UNC -- and I'm a science major, not an English major. Seriously -- make sure you have a class with her before you leave UNC.
She is fabulous! So ridiculously smart--take her class! She's great to talk to one-on-one, and she's great with a big class. Discussion is always awesome. I love love loved this class.

Professor Thrailkill is one of the best professors I've had at UNC. She gives great insight into the readings and really values students' input. She wants you to understand the material, and cares that you do. She will never make a student feel dumb for volunteering in class and is a very fair grader.

Prof Thrailkill is one of the best professors I've ever had. Her lectures are clear and interesting. Reading was usually one short story per class, which was manageable, and essay grading was fair. She's also really nice and helpful outside of class. Oh - she learned all our names, and it was a big class! Take her, you won't be sorry!

She is the BEST professor I have ever had - hands down. I went into her class as a science major, pretty much hating all lit classes. She was so helpful throughout the semester, and she has new ways of looking at the readings that are so awesome and refreshing. When the class was over I was an English major, and that pretty much says it all.
She is amazing!  One of the best professors I've had at UNC.  I took this class after reading previous reviews on RateMyProfessor and I am SO glad I did!

The epitome of pure genius.  Honest to God, I look forward to coming to this class...her lectures are fantastic and her grasp of the material is amazing.  If this class were three hours long, each and every day, I would gladly attend.  She's a fair grader and an excellent professor...if you can take her, do.
she is amazing! her lectures are so interesting! and she is such a sweetheart and a huge help outside of class!
Professor Thrailkill is great!  Her class is very fun; we watch videos a lot.  There is a lot of reading required, though, so this isn't a class to take if you have no time for work.

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: This is an AMAZING professor - she's not exactly an easy grader, but no good English professor is. She expects a lot of you, and if you put the bar high for yourself you'll do very well. I highly recommend taking this professor if you have a love of the Victorian period. Funny, engaged, and she cares.

Prof. Taylor is extremely engaging and pleasant and has many insightful things to say about all of the works covered in class. Do note that this class is 90% poetry. I entered this class vastly preferring prose but Prof. Taylor made me love poetry!

I'm kind of appalled at the comment saying she's "sickingly" nice. No, she's genuinely nice! She cares about students, is willing to write recommendations, etc! Knows her 19th c. british and courtly love type stuff cold. Very feminine focus to her classes. Survey-like too. Don't take if that's not for you. I liked her classes (FYS, 121, 338) a lot!

I disliked her class. She is "nice" but in a sickeningly fake way.  This is one of my least favorite English classes (I'm an English major).  There are much better professors out there - don't waste your time on this one.  Class was boring.

Very interesting class! Read mostly books from highschool, but looked at them in a new light.  Subjective grading, so beware. I didn't read anything (except Sparknotes) and pulled off an A-.  Only grades are reading journals, participation, and a really fun final project.  Highly recommended FYS!
Great professor!  One of the best.
No Comments

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: Dr. Richards' class was my favorite of the semester! She's nice and approachable, and loves what she teaches. Made poetry fun and interesting, and is willing to talk to you outside of class and helpful when you do. Values hearing from the students and working with them in class.

Intelligent, nice teacher. But class meetings lacked organization. No clear links between authors and not enough historical context. And you had virtually no idea what your grade was all semester. She's helpful if you go to office hours but doesn't seem to care much unless your questionpaper topic is similar to her research interests.

Dr. Richards is a sweet woman who cares deeply for each of her students. She helps those who need it without making you feel dumb or insignificant. There was work but nothing unreasonable. I would say she is the best professor I've had in my two semesters at UNC. I truly don't understand where any of these negative reviews came from, she is great!!
well sometimes she'd talk about books she hadn't read.  someone would ask a question and she'd say so.  not sure what the point of most the lectures was.  also, a 100 question final.

I've taken lots of English classes and I HATED this one. Some of that has to do with my TA, but Eliza was a horrible lecturer. So boring and so scatterbrained! Stay away. There are much better English profs out there.

I thought she was a great professor.  I loved the material she picked (easy Poe, Hawthorne, Frederick Douglass).  She is obviously very knowledgeable in these areas.  She's a little scatter-brained - changes her mind about some assignments.  But she's always very helpful and easy to access and work with.  I loved this class!

I had the complete opposite experience with her.  She required an unreasonable amount of work, was not clear on her expectations, and was EXTREMELY rude and unhelpful.  I felt unwelcome in the class and got the sense that she is only concerned with students who share her academic interests.  Her class caused me a huge amount of stress!
She was kind and helpful, not demanding really and she clearly enjoyed being there every day.  A good teacher especially for non-english-majors picking up a perspective class.

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: Dr. Ho broadened my understanding of the texts. She doesn't suffer fools gladly, but she's an excellent teacher if you WANT to be taught.
She is a very difficult professor for a first year seminar. I think that she tries to help but is difficult to approach.

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: Professor Kim was great. She found a way to make the entire Asian American Lit class about the Japanese American Incarceration, which turned out to be really interesting. There is a lot of reading for this class, and if you do not read, you will likely not do well on the essays/final exam. Some people had problems with this class, but I loved it!

Dr. Kim was an interesting professor to have. The entire course surrounded the Japanese American incarceration, which frankly I'm shocked could be an entire class. While I did enjoy some aspects of the class, I found some parts to be a bit mundane, in addition to Dr. Kim's voice sometimes drawing my attention away. Nonetheless, she's very nice!

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: Professor Fisher is arguably one of the worst professors I have ever had. The class was extremely unorganized and in the span of two days we had 18 pages of writing assigned to us simply because she could not keep up with her earlier deadlines. Although she is certainly intelligent, she shows no signs of making her class a priority. DO NOT TAKE

She is very smart, but sometimes too much for the good of the class. Never returns papers that are assigned, and moved around deadlines and assignments because she took so long grading papers. The class on a day to day basis was discussion. You have to keep up with the reading because she randomly calls on students!

She is very smart but doesn't convey the material well. Some of the things she taught didn't seem relevant to what the class was supposed to be about. When she spoke to you it seemed like she was speaking down to you. She had an arrogant air about her when she talked and it made me wary/ uncomfortable to go to her for help.

Dr. Fisher is intelligent, and expects a TON from her students.  I think that the course load was extremely high for a first-year seminar.  Also, Dr. Fisher is not an easy grader by any stretch of the imagination.  If you are a freshman looking for a stress-free seminar, this might not be the one for you.  Although, you would certainly learn a lot!

Like others have said, she's a very intelligent and well spoken woman. I definitely learned a lot from her. I do think she expects too much and grades papers hard. You cannot miss more than 2 classes without having your grade lowered & you MUST keep up with readings because she will call on anyone at anytime.

took Intro to Literary Criticism with her and was blown away. Her class is intense - you're very much expected to participate, so you better keep up with the readings. She's a brilliant professor and incredibly well spoken, and she definitely wants her students to succeed. Try to take a class with her if you can!

Dr. Fisher was an amazing teacher - incredibly smart (almost too smart) and interesting, but I found the courseload way too high for a first year seminar. I learned a lot and I think I'm a better writer because of the class, but if you're interested in her class be prepared to write a TON.

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: Ruthless grader, despite receiving positive feedback.

one of the best professors I've had yet, and one of my favorite classes. her dainty british accent and sweet demeanor are juxtaposed with her unexpectedly crude humor. she makes the material fascinating and exciting, and her exams/papers are really well structured. she grades fair. could not recommend more!!!! read and come to class

Professor Cooper is wonderful.  She's irreverent and funny and just about all the things you want in a professor.  You do have to do the reading, but the syllabus is great, so it's not like it's a hassle.  A plus plus plus.

Do yourself a favor and take her class, she's supermegafoxyawesome. It is essential that you do the reading, because the discussions won't give you the info. You'll want to know where your towel is even if you don't feel like participating. Really, really funny and a fantastic teacher.  Grade is from papers/final and her grading isn't harsh at all.

Do not leave UNC without taking a class with this woman! Her classes are so interesting and she's a great teacher and she's hilarious! Classes are pretty much self-guided discussion, which is great if you enjoy that. Def need to participate in class so make sure you do the reading - she might ask for your opinion. AWESOME LADY!

Excellent syllabus, good mix of theory and literature, extremely knowledgeable about the subject.  Her comments on papers were very useful, and she is very good at guiding research projects.  I hope to take another class with her.
Watch your grammar and citations on papers! Also, the discussions tend to be a little unguided, make sure you comprehend the main issues in the books.

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: Professor Anderson is hands-down one of the most interesting and innovative professors on UNC's campus.  If you have the chance to take a class with him: DO IT!  The skills and composition techniques you learn will be invaluable.  I am almost sad that I didn't fail his class just to take it again.  Almost.

For his MultiMedia class: Really cool teacher. Always there when someone needed assistance. Instructions were occasionally slightly unclear, but he graded in regards to difficulties that people would be having. Kind of an easy class, he wants you to do well. Book was not needed.
Wonderful class. Use of new media such as web essays, mashups, and portfolios is excellent. Can't wait to take another class!

I took this class over the summer and it was great. Just do the assignments he gives and you will do well. He uses multiple forms of technology which is also fun. He is really nice and willing to help with anything you need. GREAT CLASS

This class was different then the normal english comp class.                        Dan displayed enthusiasm for his subject and a desire to share it with the students. Dan also set clear goals, used valid and appropriate assessment methods, and provided high-quality feedback on the assignments.
:) :) :) Favorite class of my career!
Dan is a teacher that requires you to ask your own questions and interpret things your own way, even when he doesn't say you need to. If you're cool with that, you should definitely enjoy his class.
Probably one of the most interesting classes I've ever taken. He doesn't do things normally, and that's what makes his class so much fun.

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: Professor Taylor is among the worst professors I've had in the humanities. He doesn't offer any meaningful insight or analysis but relies on slow, soft-headed class discussion. Classes are tedious and fruitless. Compares unfavorably to most instructors. An unreasonably tough grader for the low quality of the course.

The novels he picks are interesting, but his discussions aren't. It's nice that he truly wants feedback from students. Unfortunately, the class time felt like a caricature of an English class: a lot of his analysis didn't match the text. On top of that, he grades harshly. A B is doable, but don't expect to be engaged during class.

Dr. Taylor was an amazing professor: he gave great lectures, chose awesome novels, and was all-around funny, nice, and inspiring. Really willing to helptalk about assignments. He's a tough grader, I'm not going to lie, but you really grow as a writer and critical thinker. I've learned to look at literature in a totally new way thanks to him!

Good professor. Takes the material and papers very seriously. Easier to talk to 1 on 1 than you might imagine. He is kind and fair. Do the readings, though- he likes to give 'pop quizzes' on the material that make it really obvious if you haven't done the reading. Proofread your essays carefully!

He values students' feedback and is a very insightful prof. He's fun and engaging, but take the papers seriously, they're no joke! His Popular Genres class is especially great, we read detective novels, sci-fi, and Batman among other texts covered in this course. I also took American lit with him which was just as good.

He's a great professor; he strikes a good balance between productive class discussion and a little lecturing when we needed it. He provides lots of feedback and grades fairly. He's approachable and knowledgeable. Highly recommend!

I really loved taking a class with Prof. Taylor; he teaches the American Novel as a popular genres course, which most professors do not do. He brings up interesting discussions and leads class well. He's a very tough grader though, so run ideas for papers by him before writing them

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: Professor Salvaggio is on top of my list for best professor ever. She is very knowledgeable, fair, and kind and her class feels almost like a meditation class. One word of advice though; she is very kind but not stupid, so dont expect a good grade unless you show up to every class and do the readings.
Great teacher! Very helpful and interesting.
Great professor! Don't leave UNC without taking her class.

A solid teacher who's passionate about her subject and very kind. Sometimes the lectures wander, but she's so enthusiastic I didn't mind. Easy class to do well in if you keep up with the readings and attend class.

Spends classtime leading discussions about topics that are sometimes relevant and sometimes not relevant to the assigned material.  Rarely covers assigned readings or stays on a time table.  Interesting most of the time anyway.  Class is extremely easy to get an A in, but can be difficult to adjust to if you are used to lecture/note teaching.
Very easy class, but incredibly dull. Lectures were never well-planned and were all opinionated. If you have any opinion at all about Literature, you're fine.

This was a pretty easy class--one paper, one test. There was a lot of reading, and she does go off in crazy tangents, but she was usually interesting and she always welcomed comments. This is definetly a class for people who love literature and want to discuss it, so don't take from her if you are just looking for a class to get by in.

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: How can this person claim to have a PHD
No Comments
The best English teacher I've ever had! Very clear and always willing to help.

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: I took Dr. Langbauer's 19th cent. Brit lit class hoping to better understanding some of the best literary works the English language has to offer. Dr. Langbauer's lectures are incredibly long and can be very confusing at times (she jumps around a lot). I think that she really tries, but the large lecture format of this class needs to be changed.

I've had three classes with Dr. Langbauer and loved every one of them. Her classes gave the freedom to engage in research and projects that I not only enjoyed, but yielded more than just an end of semester paper. She has taught me much and is the reason I was able to go on and publish one of my first essays.

So, I'm not done with the class yet and may end up getting a good grade, but wow. She's extremely knowledgeable and seems like a nice person--but that's not what makes a good teacher. Her midterms are preposterously hard. No matter how much you might study, it's all extremely specific, dumb things. I'm learning very little. Steer clear.

I adore this professor! Her lectures were entertaining and very informative. Her class was a very healthy balance of a straightforward, multiple choice midterm, a couple papers, and a short essay final. The only issue is that grading is up to the TAs, so your experience there could be good or bad.

Adorable, just adorable. She's a great professor - funny and engaging, she really makes an effort to entertain students while educating us. You *have* to do the reading to do well in the class, and the multiple choice midterms are tricky, but otherwise a great professor.

For Langbauer's class she leaves the grading to the TAs: not cool. Instead try to get into a class where the professor grades your work. It may be harder and your grade may not be as high, but you will gain more from the experience.

Dr. Langbauer is a mildly entertaining lecturer but she is prone moralizing and only presents her own reading of a work. She is very knowledgable but if you care about the subject this can get annoying. You MUST read all the books but they're some of the best books ever written. For an English class the writing is minimal and the grading is fair.

I hated this class -- Dr. Langbaur's multiple choice tests are demeaning and only care about straight facts. They are extremely poor indicators of whether or not you've actually learned. Her power point presentations over animated and all of her lectures are sporadic, incoherent, and feel like a waste of time. Not for the serious student.

Easy class if you're not a slacker student. Lectures are hard to follow sometimes but she makes really quirky powerpoints that provide entertainment. Def need to do all the reading to do well on her tests, which are all multiple choice and can be tricky sometimes. I've had her twice and have enjoyed both her classes.
Enthusiastic and happy teacher, with slightly tricky midterms but awesome reading material.  The powerpoints made me giggle.

No attendance policy.  I went to maybe two of the lectures and only to a few of the recitations the entire semester and somehow still managed to get a B in the class.  Two multiple-choice midterms (that are curved very generously), a paper, an open-book/note final, and a recitation/participation grade.  If you make any effort whatsoever you should
She was very nice, very well informed, a pretty good lecturer.  the only problem i had in this class was with her TAs.  Tests were a little difficult but there was a nice curve.
Childrens literature class was great. interesing power points.  nice lady, pretty easy multiple choice/ short essay exams (3).

the powerpoints are annoying, her witticisms leave something to be desired... but she is unpretentious, kind, sincere, and knowledgeable on her particular area of literary study, which is a pretty interesting one.

extremely knowledgable, energetic, compassionate, decidedly NOT pompous. a natural teacher and a genuinely nice person. oh, and the powerpoints are amusing (charmingly outdated) if you don't have a stick lodged in lodged in your hindquaters.

wow. she gives new meaning to the word pompous. rather than actually lecture on anything that mattered, she chose instead to do stupid power points with all the moving cartoon characters added in as she read from an essay about the subject.

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: Marr is so happy and enthusiastic about teaching and a little weird, and I loved it. He loves what he's teaching, and he knows so much about it, especially considering most of the topics were pretty out there. A ten page paper for the midterm and the final, a couple of opinion-based short essays, and that's pretty much it. Easy A, and cool class.
Marr's the man. Take this class

Very interesting professor.  Leads thought-provoking discussions and helps you to think on a higher plane.  Very available to discuss projects and willing to give helpful feedback.  Interested in students.  Most of grade is based on two main papers, which can seem daunting, but he helps and guides you as you work on each for half of the semester.

Professor Marr is probably the best professor I've had. He's extremely enthusiastic about the material, an animated, engaging lecturer, and thoroughly smart and articulate. He is heavily invested in his students--he took the time to learn all 60+ names and faces. Not an easy A: the average student is just  much smarter than the majority.

Professor Marr was an awesome guy, and he was extremely knowledgeable about his subject matter. I had such little interest in this class, and yeah, it was kinda boring for me, but professor Marr makes it so much more fun and is great at getting to know you and being a personal guy. I highly recommend this teacher.

Dr. Marr is brilliant passionate about both his subject and his students. I loved going to the lectures each week. The class is a bit disorganized, but I would highly recommend a class with Marr. His lectures broadened my perspective on American culture and history, and always left me wanting to talk about class material with friends.

TIM MARR IS THE BEST. He is very passionate about what he teaches and gives great feedback! He enjoys seeing all sides of topics and drawing them our so you can easily grasp them. I have no doubt that this class completely changed my way of thinking about everything. It was hard to adjust to the work load, but it was totally worth it! I loved it!
Dr. Marr is a genius  AND an amazing teacher. best class ever.

Very passionate and engaging.  Professor Marr made sure his classes were thought provoking and interesting.  Absolutely loved this class.  There are two major projects, both papers, and a lot of individual reading assignments.  But they are all interesting.  I recommend this seminar to anyone and everyone.
Genius. His class on Herman Melville changed how I approach literature.
MY FAVORITE teacher at UNC! Sooo interested in his subject matter and helping his students! A MUST for any Amst major especially!

Prof. Marr is very passionate about what he teaches.  He inspired us to do our best work.   There was alot of reading and writing, but you should take this class if issues of birth and death interest you.  Work consists of two major projects (papers), one on birth one on death.  I learned things unknown to me prior to class.

Professor Marr is a bit kooky, but very passionate about what he teaches and very good at engaging the class.  The work load for this class was moderate but always interesting.  You will excel in his class as long as you put forth effort and enthusiasm.

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: Extremely nice guy and very knowledgeable, but his lectures are all over the place. He talks himself in a circle and is difficult to follow

Personable, funny, and serious as hell, Shayne is truly one of UNC's best. He explains dense and complicated topics with an unparalleled combination of specificity and accessibility. He's genuinely interested and committed to his students and their scholarship; office hours are frequently extended so that all seeking help get it. Brilliant prof!

Hands down, Shayne will be the best professor you've ever had. And the hardest. He is ALWAYS available to talk, really wants you to understand, and grades kindly if you show you care. Prepare to bust your ass doing tons of really dense readings and rewriting your papers at least 3 times, but it will be the most rewarding experience of your life!

This guy is probably the most intelligent professor I've encountered in 6 years at this school. For his age, he has such a vast knowledge of his field that it is almost hard to keep up with the discussions, but that's not his fault. Extremely helpful, the classes are NOT hard, make use of his office hours. An awesome prof.

Awesome teacher!  My first class in which I can truly say that I had fun while learning.  He can be a bit tough but you will learn a great deal.  Participate in class and make use of his office hours.

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: The class was pretty easy. The assignments were fairly interesting, but lectures were a little slow.
No Comments
Almost everything was written collectively by the whole class.   Very easy.

Awesome professor, very nice and funny.  The midterms was a paper that the whole class wrote together, we got an A on it.  For papers he gives you a standard topic and a creative topic (such as rewriting a story in another style), and you get to choose which one you want to do.

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: Love him!! I only took this because it was open. not interested in Chaucer at all but became my favorite class! He is an amazing teacher and excellent at keeping you engaged! I would highly suggest taking a class from Prof O'Neill! Also he is CRAZY nice and in my top 3 professors at UNC, and don't get the book the translations are online for free..
He's an awesome teacher! He is really funny and makes a really boring subject interesting. He's a tough grader on papers but he's always willing to help.

Loved Prof. O'Neill! Made British Literature (which I think is a pretty dry subject) extremely interesting. He's great and makes it clear from the start what his expectations are. He's a tough grader, but he's more than willing to help with papers/presentations. Take him!

Great professor, really made Chaucer interesting.  Daily quizzes but just know your minor characters.  exams were tedious but no suprises, he gives you everything in his lectures.  Would take another class if he had one.  Very well recommended

Very good teacher, organized and interesting.  His tests are not cakewalks but you can make good grades with very modest amounts of studying.  The Chaucer book is not really needed, you are better off using online or paperback versions with line by line translation.
Great teacher.  Will learn a lot and have fun while doing it.

Funny guy, but grades pretty harshly. Must remember lots of dates and facts--not as much into interpretation--at least in the survey class I took with him. Makes class interesting, though, with his sense of humor!
he was good
excellent teacher, wants you to learn but also to enjoy learning
Had him for a summer course in Adult Ed.  A fab teacher and a good program organizer.  Great with the 20th cent. Irish poets.
One of my favorite English professors and one of the few I remember from my time in Chapel Hill. I definitely recommend him.
He's great - very helpful, smart, witty, and makes the whole class interesting and fun.  Take a class from him!
O'Neill rocks.  Very funny and a great teacher.  Take any class you can with him.
